moves.8. Bc4+ d5 9. Bxd5+ Kg7: There's no really safe spot for the King, but here His Royal Highness has some friends.
moves.10. Bxc6 bxc6: I'm fortunate that White voluntarily exchanges pieces. Every swap makes my task easier.
moves.11. d3 Nf6 12. Bxf4 Bb4: I try to generate my own threats and seize some of the initiative.
moves.15. Qxd2 Bd7 16. a3 Raf8 17. O-O-O Nh5: A bit of a lull allows me to strengthen my defenses.
moves.18. Qc3+ Kg6 19. e5 Qd5 20. Kb1 Rh7: Now I look to seize the offensive.
moves.21. g3 Rhf7: I begin by doubling Rooks on the open file.
moves.22. d4 Be6: I of course blockade the passed Pawn.
moves.23. b3 Qf3: I expected White to decline the Queen trade, since I'm ahead in material.
moves.26. Nxg3 Rxg3: Another exchange. I'm starting to like my chances.
moves.27. h5+ Kg5: In the end game, which we are now in, the King should be used as a weapon.
moves.29. Kb1 Rgg2: ...and double on the seventh rank, a very dangerous formation.
